General '''Sami Hafez Anan''' or '''Enan''' (born 1948) is the [[Chief of Staff]] of the [[Egyptian Armed Forces]].
+
General '''Sami Hafez Anan''' or '''Enan''' {{lang-ar|Ø³Ø§ÙÙ Ø¹ÙØ§Ù}} (born 1948) is the [[Chief of Staff]] of the [[Egyptian Armed Forces]].
When the [[2011 Egyptian protests]] began, Anan was in [[Washington]] "for a week of meetings with senior American officers".<ref name=VOA>[http://www.voanews.com/english/news/usa/US-Egypt-Military-Relationship-Might-Impact-Crisis-114979569.html US-Egypt Military Relationship Might Impact Crisis], ''[[Voice of America]]'', 31 January 2011</ref> Cutting his visit short, he returned to [[Egypt]] on Friday 28th January.<ref name=VOA/> As the commander of an army of 468,000 troops, he is likely to play a crucial role in the political uncertainty surrounding the protests.<ref>[http://www.thenews.com.pk/TodaysPrintDetail.aspx?ID=3652&Cat=13&dt=1/30/2011 Lt-Gen Sami Anan will have the final say], ''[[The News International]]'', January 30, 2011 </ref> On 1 February 2010, the UK's [[Channel 4 News]] reported that the [[United States of America]] was pressing for Anan to play a role in coordinating interim arrangements for government in [[Egypt]] after [[Hosni Mubarak]].<ref>[[Jonathan Rugman]], ''Channel 4 News'', 1 February 2010</ref>
When the [[2011 Egyptian protests]] began, Anan was in [[Washington]] "for a week of meetings with senior American officers".<ref name=VOA>[http://www.voanews.com/english/news/usa/US-Egypt-Military-Relationship-Might-Impact-Crisis-114979569.html US-Egypt Military Relationship Might Impact Crisis], ''[[Voice of America]]'', 31 January 2011</ref> Cutting his visit short, he returned to [[Egypt]] on Friday 28th January.<ref name=VOA/> As the commander of an army of 468,000 troops, he is likely to play a crucial role in the political uncertainty surrounding the protests.<ref>[http://www.thenews.com.pk/TodaysPrintDetail.aspx?ID=3652&Cat=13&dt=1/30/2011 Lt-Gen Sami Anan will have the final say], ''[[The News International]]'', January 30, 2011 </ref> On 1 February 2010, the UK's [[Channel 4 News]] reported that the [[United States of America]] was pressing for Anan to play a role in coordinating interim arrangements for government in [[Egypt]] after [[Hosni Mubarak]].<ref>[[Jonathan Rugman]], ''Channel 4 News'', 1 February 2010</ref>
